Shape: A very large songbird with a heavy body, a large head, and an extremely long tail. The bill is stout and slightly curved. The wings are wide and rounded.
Compared Size: Much larger than a California Scrub-Jay, slightly smaller than an American Crow.

description: A black-and-white bird with iridescent blue in the wings and a bright yellow bill. When perched, the shoulders and belly are stark white against the black body. In flight, the primary feathers (in the outer wing) show extensive white as well.

Walks slowly on the ground looking for grain, insects, and rodents. Flies with deep, fairly slow wingbeats. A social bird that is usually in small flocks in summer and in larger flocks during the nonbreeding season.
Nests in tall trees in oak savanna or similar habitats of central California. Forages in grassland, pasture, cultivated fields, and orchards, sometimes in trees.
